comments:
1) turn on wrap for the console
2) somewhere that is going to get hit and have a decent size traceback, put the 
line:
         new Error().printStackTrace();

(Attached is the entry that was being printed to the console when the error 
happened.)

Created an attachment (id=1016)
example print stacktrace

Moving to platform UI - I was unable to cause the problem, but the stack trace 
is UI (JFace) and SWT code. Could be difficult to reproduce, as it looks like 
the debug perspective was being opened and created at the time the console was 
being written to. I attempted to reproduce by putting a breakpoint right after 
the "print stack trace", and closed the debug perspective in my host.

I suspect that the problem is caused by enabling text wrapping. The TextViewer 
used in the console's implementation does not support the SWT.WRAP flag. Won't 
change for 2.0. Propose to remove the wrap flag for 2.0.

Moving to Debug UI.

The console view is a subclass of TextViewer which creates a StyledText widget 
for its view. The StyledText widget claims to support SWT.WRAP. What do you 
mean it does not support WRAP?
*** Bug 18941 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Additionally, the base delay of 50ms no longer seems to be enough for programs 
that write massive output. Increasing the polling delay to 100ms appears to 
free up the UI thread to allow the user to terminate "run away" programs.

Will have to remove WRAP support and replace with console specific line 
wrap/truncation. Marking as F3 candidate.

Fixed. Changed preference to toggle fixed console width, and added console 
width peference (see debug console pref page). Console performs automatic 
wrapping (internal implementation) when preference is set. Pref is off by 
default.
*** Bug 19849 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
